[.chapter]
[@id:287911]
[▼ch-1]
[#cloze (gap text)]

[.info:bitmark--]
[@id:287912]
Defines a cloze (gap text) to be filled by short free text.

bit.body: Defines a cloze (gap text) to be filled by short free text.

bitmark:
[.cloze]
[@id:287913]
[%][%cloze]
This sentence is a [_cloze][_gap text][!noun] with [_two][?one or two] gaps including an instruction for the first and a hint for the second gap.

bit.body: This sentence is a {0} with {1} gaps including an instruction for the first and a hint for the second gap.

[@id:287915]
Please see ==cloze==|link:https://docs.bitmark.cloud/quizzes/#cloze-gap-text| for the documentation of all tags. This section contains the additional tags only.

All **instructions [ !...]** of the cloze are collected and displayed together as a help for the user.

bitmark:
[.info:bitmark++]
[@id:287920]
Please see ==cloze==|link:https://docs.bitmark.cloud/quizzes/#cloze-gap-text| for the documentation of all tags.

@countSolutions: true
Solutions will be counted and have to be displayed by the client (in the grouped solutions)

@additionalSolutions: This is another potential solution, which is not part of any quiz]
Sometimes you need to provide more potential solutions for a quiz than actually exist. For example, all quizzes have the solution **true**, but you need to provide the potential solution **false** for the quiz to make sense.

errors.errorLine: @additionalSolutions: This is another potential solution, which is not part of any quiz]

bitmark:
[.chapter]
[@id:287921]
[▼ch-4]
[#multiple-choice, multiple-choice-1]

[.info:bitmark--]
[@id:287922]
Defines a multiple choice quiz.

A multiple choice quiz gives you multiple potential answers to select from, but only one is correct.

In german speaking countries, this is called a "single choice quiz".

bit.body:
Defines a multiple choice quiz.

A multiple choice quiz gives you multiple potential answers to select from, but only one is correct.

In german speaking countries, this is called a "single choice quiz".

bitmark:
[.note:bitmark++]
[@id:287923]
Multiple choice quizzes are sometimes used as true/false quizzes. There is no problem with that. However, please be aware that bitmark JSON defines a ==true/false==|link:https://docs.bitmark.cloud/quizzes/#true-false-true-false-1| quiz for this.

bit.body: Multiple choice quizzes are sometimes used as true/false quizzes. There is no problem with that. However, please be aware that bitmark JSON defines a ==true/false==|link:https://docs.bitmark.cloud/quizzes/#true-false-true-false-1| quiz for this.

bitmark:
[.multiple-choice-1]
[@id:287924]
[%][%multiple-choice-1]
[!What color is milk?]
[?Cows produce milk.]
[+white]
[-red]
[-blue]

bit.instruction: What color is milk?

bitmark:
[.multiple-choice]
[@id:287925]
[%][%multiple-choice]
[!What color do the following beverages have?]
Be careful and think twice.
===
[!Milk]
[+white]
[-red]
[-blue]
===
[!Red Wine]
[+red]
[-white][%12]
[-green][@example]
===

bit.instruction: What color do the following beverages have?
bit.body: Be careful and think twice.

[.multiple-response]
[@id:287929]
[%][%multiple-response]
[!What colors can animals have in Switzerland?]
===
[!What colours can cows have in Switzerland?]
[+brown]
[+purple][?In chocolate ads]
[-blue]
===
[!What colours can cats have in Switzerland?]
[+brown]
[+black]
[+blue]
[+green]
===

bit.instruction: What colors can animals have in Switzerland?

quizzes.instruction: What colours can cows have in Switzerland?
What colours can cats have in Switzerland?

bitmark:
[.note:bitmark++]
[@id:287930]
In order to be able to distinguish between unselected and unprocessed answers in the evaluation, sometimes two boxes per question are used for "yes" and "no". Please refer to ==true/false quiz==|link:https://docs.bitmark.cloud/quizzes/#true-false-true-false-1|.

bit.body: In order to be able to distinguish between unselected and unprocessed answers in the evaluation, sometimes two boxes per question are used for "yes" and "no". Please refer to ==true/false quiz==|link:https://docs.bitmark.cloud/quizzes/#true-false-true-false-1|.

||in the documentation it has sample solutions, but they only work in sandbox, not in cosmic ||

[%a]What was your last job?[!Please answer in one short sentence]
[@example:I worked as a project manager.][@shortAnswer]
===
[%b]Why did you quit your last job?[!Please answer in several short sentences]
===
[%c]How much did you earn in your last job?[!Please use Euro as a currency][@shortAnswer]
===

bit.instruction: This is a job interview with an example, model answers and line "numbers".

questions.question: What was your last job?
questions.instruction: Please answer in one short sentence

questions.question: Why did you quit your last job?
questions.instruction: Please answer in several short sentences

questions.question: How much did you earn in your last job?
questions.instruction: Please use Euro as a currency

[@id:287975]

[#true-false]

[.info:bitmark--]
[@id:287976]
Describes a true/false quiz. It allows for several true-false quizzes in a bit and provides support for alternative labels for the values true and false. Please also see true-false-1 for a simpler format.

bit.body: Describes a true/false quiz. It allows for several true-false quizzes in a bit and provides support for alternative labels for the values true and false. Please also see true-false-1 for a simpler format.

bitmark:
[.true-false]
[@id:287977]
[%][%true-false]
[@labelTrue:rather yes][@labelFalse:rather no]
===
[+A house is bigger than a car.]
===
[+A tiger is bigger than a cat.]
===
[-A cow is bigger than a dog.]
===

statements.statement: A house is bigger than a car.
A tiger is bigger than a cat.
A cow is bigger than a dog.

bitmark:
[.info:bitmark--]
[@id:287978]
__Multiple true/false statements and an instruction__

bit.body: __Multiple true/false statements and an instruction__

bitmark:
[.true-false]
[@id:287979]
[%][%true-false]
[!What colors can cows have in Switzerland?]
===
[+brown]
===
[+purple, but only in chocolate ads]
===
[-blue]
===
[-green]
===

bit.instruction: What colors can cows have in Switzerland?

[.info:bitmark--]
[@id:287980]

[&image:https://docs.bitmark.cloud/bit-books/gmb/quiz_book/web-resources/images/gmb_quiz_book_cat.png][@width:928]
===
[-On the picture, you see a mouse.]
===
[+There is a cat on the picture.]
===

statements.statement: On the picture, you see a mouse.
There is a cat on the picture.

[.info:bitmark--]
[@id:287982]
Applications must translate the values true and false into the language of the user interface when displaying.

bit.body: Applications must translate the values true and false into the language of the user interface when displaying.

**Assignment** is very close to an ==article==|link:https://docs.bitmark.cloud/quizzes/#article|. The difference is, that this is a "quiz" and therefore has an instruction property. The distinction is important for display, sharing, ...
